tasks.title: What is Software? Types of Software‚Äôs?
What is Software Testing?
tasks.description: Software testing a part of developing a software and making sure the software is working as per the requirement of user or customer request or needs

tasks.title: What is Software Quality?
tasks.description:
What is software Testing Quality? the objective of testing is to release quality product to the client and  Software testing quality  should be 
1. Bug free
2. Delivered on Time
3. Within Budget.
4. Meets requirements and or expectations of customers
5. Maintainable

tasks.title: SDLC
tasks.description:
The SDLC (Software Development Life Cycle) is a structured process used to plan, build, test, deploy, and maintain software. It ensures software is delivered with quality, on time, and within budget.
üîπ SDLC Process (Simple & Clear)
1. Requirement Gathering
Understand what the customer wants.

Document all functional and non‚Äëfunctional requirements.

2. Feasibility Study
Check if the project is technically, financially, and operationally possible.

3. System Design
Create high‚Äëlevel and low‚Äëlevel designs.

Decide architecture, database design, UI design, and technology stack.

4. Implementation / Coding
Developers write the actual code based on the design.

5. Testing
Testers verify the software for defects.

Includes unit, integration, system, and acceptance testing.

6. Deployment
Release the software to production for end users.

7. Maintenance
Fix issues, update features, and improve performance after release.

tasks.title: Waterfall Model
tasks.description:
Requirement Analysis  
Gather and document all system requirements from stakeholders.

System Design  
Translate requirements into architecture and design specifications.

Implementation  
Develop the actual software code based on the design.

Testing  
Verify and validate the software to ensure it meets requirements and is bug-free.

Deployment  
Release the software to the production environment for end users.

Maintenance  
Provide ongoing support, updates, and bug fixes after deployment.
‚úÖ Advantages of the Waterfall Model
High product quality due to structured development.

Fewer bugs since requirement changes are restricted.

Lower initial investment‚Äîtesters are hired in later stages.

Ideal for small projects with fixed requirements.

‚ö†Ô∏è Disadvantages of the Waterfall Model
No flexibility for changing requirements.

Early requirement defects persist through later phases.

Higher total cost due to time-consuming rework.

Testing begins only after coding is complete.

tasks.title: Spiral Model
tasks.description:
üîÑ Spiral Model ‚Äì Overview
The Spiral Model is an iterative software development model.

It was designed to overcome the limitations of the Waterfall Model.

It is used when there is module dependency in the system.

In each cycle, new software is released to the customer.

Software is delivered in multiple versions, which is why it‚Äôs also called a version control model.

‚úÖ Advantages of the Spiral Model
Testing occurs in every cycle before moving to the next.

Customers can use software for each module, gaining early access.

Requirement changes are allowed after each cycle, offering flexibility.
‚ö†Ô∏è Disadvantages of the Spiral Model
Requirement changes are not allowed during a cycle ‚Äî only between cycles.

Each cycle resembles the Waterfall Model, which may limit agility.

No testing is done during the requirement and design phases, potentially allowing early issues to persist.

tasks.title: V-Model
tasks.description:
üîç Verification
Ensures we are building the product right.

Focuses on documentation.

Happens before validation.

Involves activities like reviews, walkthroughs, and inspections.

‚úÖ Validation
Ensures we are building the right product.

Focuses on the actual software.

Takes place after verification.

Involves unit testing, integration testing, system testing, and UAT.

tasks.title: QA & QC & QE
tasks.description:
QA is process related.
QC is the actual testing of the software.

QA focuses on building in quality.
QC focuses on testing for quality.

QA is preventing defects.
QC is detecting defects.

QA is process oriented.
QC is product oriented.

QA is for the entire life cycle.
QC is for the testing part of SDLC.
‚úÖ QA (Quality Assurance)
Process-oriented: Focuses on improving and defining processes to prevent defects.

Goal: Build quality into the product from the start.

Responsibility: Often involves managers, analysts, and process designers.

Example activities: Process audits, documentation reviews, training, standards enforcement.

‚úÖ QC (Quality Control)
Product-oriented: Involves actual testing of the software to find defects.

Goal: Verify that the product meets quality requirements.

Responsibility: Typically performed by testers and QA engineers.

Example activities: Manual testing, automation, bug reporting, regression testing.

üîÅ The "p - people / process / product" line:
People ‚Üí QC (Testers): Testers execute tests and validate the product.

Process ‚Üí QA: QA defines and improves the process to ensure quality.

Product: The final software output, shaped by both QA and QC efforts.
Please Note: QC is like manual tester sometime do automation testing 
while QE Quality Engineer is Automation Tester who write code

tasks.title: Levels of Software Testing
tasks.description:
1. Unit Testing ‚Äì Example  
A developer tests a single function, like calculateTotal(), to ensure it returns the correct value for different inputs.

2. Integration Testing ‚Äì Example  
After combining the Login module and the User Dashboard module, testers verify that a user can log in and the correct dashboard loads without errors.

3. System Testing ‚Äì Example  
Testers validate the entire e‚Äëcommerce application end‚Äëto‚Äëend: browsing products, adding to cart, checkout, payment, and order confirmation.

4. Acceptance Testing ‚Äì Example  
Business users perform UAT to confirm the system meets their needs ‚Äî for example, verifying that a refund workflow matches the company‚Äôs real business process.

tasks.title: System Testing Types
tasks.description:
System Testing
System testing is the process of testing the complete functionality of an application based on the client‚Äôs requirements. It is a black-box testing technique performed by the testing team. This type of testing is conducted after component testing and integration testing. It requires a clear understanding of customer requirements and expectations.
System testing focuses on the following aspects:
- User Interface Testing (GUI)
- Functional Testing
- Non-Functional Testing
- Usability Testing

tasks.title: GUI Testing
tasks.description:
User Interface Testing (GUI) focuses on verifying that the graphical elements of an application function correctly and meet design specifications. It ensures that:
- üñ±Ô∏è All UI components (buttons, menus, icons, forms) are present, responsive, and behave as expected.
- üé® Visual consistency is maintained across screens‚Äîfonts, colors, spacing, and alignment match the design.
- üì± Cross-platform compatibility is validated‚ÄîUI behaves properly on different devices, browsers, and resolutions.
- üß™ Interactive elements respond to user actions like clicks, hovers, and keyboard input.
- üö´ Error messages and validations appear correctly when users input invalid data.
- üîç Accessibility standards are met‚Äîscreen readers, keyboard navigation, and contrast ratios are tested.

tasks.title: Functional
tasks.description:
Functionality Testing
1)- Object Properties Testing
Example: Check if the ‚ÄúSubmit‚Äù button is enabled only after all required fields are filled.
2)- Database Testing
Example: Verify that a new user registration correctly inserts data into the users table.
- Error Handling
Example: Enter invalid email format and confirm the system shows a clear error message.
3)- Calculations / Manipulations Testing
Example: Add items to cart and verify the total price is calculated correctly with tax and discount.
4)- Links Existence & Links Execution
Example: Confirm that the ‚ÄúForgot Password‚Äù link is visible and navigates to the correct page.
5)- Cookies & Sessions
Example: Log in and check that a session cookie is created and persists until logout.
üç™ Cookies
Temporary files created by the browser while browsing pages on the internet.
‚è≥ Sessions
Time slots created by the server. A session will expire after some time (especially if you're idle).

tasks.title: Use case, Test scenario & Test case
Type of Testing Techniques
tasks.description:
We have Two types of testing techniques one is static and another is dynamic . Static testing is all related to documents while Dynamic testing techniques is related to main software testing 
***Static Testing Technique****
1, Review
2, Walkthrough
3, Inspection

***Dynamic testing Technique***
1,Unit Testing(testing singe module )
2,Integration testing ( testing multiple modules ) both unit and integration tests are done by developer and it is called white  box test because the developer know about the code briefly so that's why called white box testing 
3,System testing done by QA and called black box testing beacuase the QA don't know about the code inside 
4, User Acceptance Testing is done by cline or customer

tasks.title: STLC
tasks.description:
üîπ STLC (Software Testing Life Cycle)
STLC is a step‚Äëby‚Äëstep process followed during testing to ensure software quality. It defines how testing is planned, designed, executed, and closed.

STLC Phases (Simple & Clear)
1. Requirement Analysis
Understand what needs to be tested.

Identify testable and non‚Äëtestable requirements.

Clarify gaps with BA/Dev if needed.

2. Test Planning
Define the testing strategy.

Estimate effort, resources, timelines.

Identify tools and risks.

3. Test Case Design
Write detailed test cases.

Prepare test data.

Review and finalize test scenarios.

4. Test Environment Setup
Prepare the environment where testing will run.

Install builds, configure servers, databases, tools.

5. Test Execution
Execute test cases.

Log defects.

Retest and perform regression testing.

6. Test Closure
Ensure all planned tests are completed.

Prepare test summary report.

Evaluate quality and lessons learned.

tasks.title: Non-Functional Testing
tasks.description:
1. Performance Testing
(Load Testing, Stress Testing, Volume Testing)
- Load Testing:
We gradually increase the load ‚Äî for example, 1 user, then 2 users, then 3 users, and so on ‚Äî up to the required limit.
- Stress Testing:
We suddenly add a high load (e.g., +20 users at once) or suddenly remove a large number of users (e.g., ‚Äì100 users) to see how the system behaves under extreme conditions.
- Volume Testing:
We check how much data the system can handle ‚Äî how much data storage or data volume it can afford without performance issues.

2. Security Testing
(Authentication and Authorization)
- Authentication: Verifies the user is who they claim to be (login, password, OTP).
- Authorization: Verifies what the user is allowed to access after login (roles, permissions).

3. Recovery Testing
Checks how well the system recovers from crashes, failures, or unexpected shutdowns.

4. Compatibility Testing
- Forward Compatibility: Supports newer versions (e.g., new browser version).
- Backward Compatibility: Supports previous versions.
- Hardware Compatibility: Works correctly on different hardware configurations.

5. Configuration Testing
Tests the application under different configurations (OS, browsers, network settings, memory, CPU, etc.).

6. Installation Testing
Checks installation and uninstallation processes to ensure they work smoothly without errors.

7. Sanitation / Garbage Testing
Ensures there are no extra or unwanted features that the customer did not request.
Example:
A developer adds a new page or feature that was not part of the requirement ‚Äî this should be flagged.

tasks.title: Object properties testing
tasks.description:
Object properties testing: Check the properties of objects present on the Application.
Ex: Enable, disable, visible, Focus...
Database Testing / Backend Testing
DML Operations (Data Manipulation Language):
- insert
- update
- delete
- select
1. Object Properties Testing ‚Äì Examples
Example 1: Login Button (Enabled/Disabled)
- Scenario: User enters username but leaves password empty
- Expected: Login button should remain disabled
Example 2: Submit Button Visibility
- Scenario: User selects ‚ÄúOther‚Äù in a dropdown
- Expected: A text field labeled ‚ÄúPlease specify‚Äù becomes visible
Example 3: Focus Check
- Scenario: User presses the Tab key on the login page
- Expected: Cursor moves from Username ‚Üí Password ‚Üí Login Button in correct order
Example 4: Field Enabled/Disabled
- Scenario: User checks ‚ÄúSame as Billing Address‚Äù
- Expected: Shipping address fields become disabled

2. Database Testing (DML Operations) ‚Äì Examples
INSERT Example
- Action: User registers a new account
- Expected DB Result: A new row is inserted into users table with correct username, email, and timestamp
UPDATE Example
- Action: User updates their profile picture
- Expected DB Result: profile_image column in users table is updated for that user ID
DELETE Example
- Action: User deletes an item from their shopping cart
- Expected DB Result: Corresponding row is removed from cart_items table
SELECT Example
- Action: User logs in
- Expected DB Result: System runs a SELECT query to fetch user credentials and returns correct user record

tasks.title: Gray Box testing
tasks.description:
Gray box testing means the tester has partial knowledge of how the system works internally and uses that information to design better tests.
Example:
You know the database has a unique email constraint, so during registration you try entering an email that already exists to verify the system shows the correct error. and don't know who the login code functionality work that only developer know that's why it is called gray box testing

tasks.title: Data Base Testing
tasks.description:
üóÑÔ∏è Database Testing / Backend Testing
üîπ DML Operations (Data Manipulation Language)
- Insert ‚Üí User registers a new account; a new row is inserted into the users table.
- Update ‚Üí User changes their phone number; the contact_number field is updated in the database.
- Delete ‚Üí User deletes a saved address; the corresponding row is removed from addresses table.
- Select ‚Üí System fetches user profile details during login using a SELECT query.

üîπ Table & Column Level Validations
- Column Type ‚Üí Ensure email column is of type VARCHAR, not INT.
- Column Length ‚Üí Verify username column allows up to 50 characters.
- Number of Columns ‚Üí Check that orders table has exactly 8 columns as per design.

üîπ Relations Between Tables (Normalization)
- Ensure customer_id in orders table correctly links to customers table via foreign key.
- Verify no redundant data exists across tables (e.g., address stored separately, not repeated).

üîπ Functions
- Test a function that calculates total cart value based on item prices and quantities.
üîπ Procedures
- Validate a stored procedure that processes order placement and updates inventory.
üîπ Triggers
- Check that a trigger automatically logs changes to user_status in an audit table.
üîπ Indexes
- Ensure index on email column speeds up login query performance.
üîπ Views
- Test a view that shows active users with recent orders, combining data from multiple tables.

tasks.title: Useability Testing
tasks.description:
Useability means easiness  
Developer should provide help menu or manual pdf document for user instructions how to use the application 
Usability Testing evaluates how easy, intuitive, and pleasant it is for real users to interact with the application. It focuses on the human experience, not just functionality. Strong usability testing helps ensure that users can complete tasks smoothly without confusion or frustration.
üåü What Usability Testing Checks
- Ease of navigation
Users should move through the application without getting lost or needing instructions.
- Learnability
New users should understand how to use the system quickly, without a steep learning curve.
- Efficiency
Common tasks should require minimal steps and effort.
- Error prevention & recovery
The system should prevent mistakes where possible and provide clear, helpful messages when errors occur.
- User satisfaction
The overall experience should feel smooth, intuitive, and pleasant.
- Accessibility
The application should support users with disabilities‚Äîkeyboard navigation, screen readers, proper contrast, etc.
üéØ Why It Matters
Even a perfectly functional system fails if users struggle to use it. Usability testing ensures the product feels natural and user‚Äëfriendly, which directly impacts adoption, satisfaction, and business success.
